description: Interactions between living things and their environment.

slides.title: What is an Ecosystem?
slides.content:
# Life Support üåç

A community of living organisms (Biotic) interacting with non-living components (Abiotic).
- **Biotic**: Animals, Plants, Bacteria.
- **Abiotic**: Water, Sunlight, Soil, Temperature.

slides.title: Trophic Levels
slides.content:
# Food Chain üçî

1. **Producers** (Autotrophs): Plants making energy from Sun.
2. **Primary Consumers** (Herbivores): Eat plants.
3. **Secondary Consumers** (Carnivores): Eat meat.
4. **Decomposers**: Break down waste (Fungi).

slides.title: Energy Flow
slides.content:
# 10% Rule üìâ

Energy is lost as heat at each step.
- Only ~10% of energy is transferred to the next level.
- This is why there are fewer Tigers (Top predators) than Zebras.

slides.title: Food Webs
slides.content:
# Tangled Web üï∏Ô∏è

Multiple interconnected food chains.
- More realistic than a simple chain.
- Removing one species can collapse the web (Keystone Species).

slides.title: Biomes: Forests
slides.content:
# Trees üå≤

- **Tropical Rainforest**: High biodiversity, poor soil (Nutrients are in the trees).
- **Temperate Deciduous**: Seasonal leaf drop.
- **Taiga (Boreal)**: Conifers, cold winters.

slides.title: Biomes: Deserts
slides.content:
# Dry üåµ

Low precipitation.
- Not always hot! (Antarctica is a desert).
- Plants adapt to store water (Cactus).
- Animals nocturnal to avoid heat.

slides.title: Biome Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Which biome is characterized by having the highest biodiversity?

slides.title: Biodiversity
slides.content:
# Variety is Life ü¶ú

- **Genetic Diversity**: Variation within species.
- **Species Diversity**: Number of different species.
- **Ecosystem Diversity**: Variety of habitats.
Higher biodiversity = More resilient ecosystem.

slides.title: Ecological Succession
slides.content:
# Recovery üå±

- **Primary**: Starting from bare rock (Volcano). Lichens first.
- **Secondary**: Starting from soil (Forest fire). Grasses/Shrubs first.
- Ends in **Climax Community** (Stable forest).

slides.title: Carrying Capacity
slides.content:
# Limits üõë

Maximum population an environment can sustain.
- Limited by food, water, space.
- Overshoot leads to crash.

slides.title: Niche vs Habitat
slides.content:
# Job vs Home üè†

- **Habitat**: Where you live (The forest).
- **Niche**: What you do (Eat insects at night).
- No two species can occupy the exact same niche (Competition).

slides.title: Symbiosis
slides.content:
# Relationships üíë

- **Mutualism**: Both win (Bee & Flower).
- **Commensalism**: One wins, other unaffected (Bird on Rhino).
- **Parasitism**: One wins, other hurt (Tick on Dog).

slides.title: Relation Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: A relationship where one organism benefits and the other is harmed is called:

slides.title: Invasive Species
slides.content:
# Invaders üëΩ

Non-native species that harm the ecosystem.
- No natural predators.
- Outcompete locals.
- Examples: Cane Toads, Kudzu, Lionfish.

slides.title: Biogeochemical Cycles
slides.content:
# Recycling Matter ‚ôªÔ∏è

- Water, Carbon, Nitrogen, Phosphorus cycles.
- Matter is recycled, Energy flows one way (Sun $\to$ Heat).

slides.title: Biomes: Tundra
slides.content:
# Frozen Plains ‚ùÑÔ∏è

- Permafrost (Permanently frozen soil).
- Small plants, no trees.
- Fragile ecosystem.

slides.title: Biomes: Grasslands
slides.content:
# Savanna & Prairie üåæ

- Ruled by grazing herds (Bison, Wildebeest).
- Frequent fires prevent trees from taking over.

slides.title: Aquatic Ecosystems
slides.content:
# Underwater üêü

- **Freshwater**: Lakes, Rivers (Low salt).
- **Marine**: Oceans, Coral Reefs (High salt).
- **Estuaries**: Mixing zone (Brackish). Nurseries for fish.

slides.title: Eco Summary
slides.content:
# Recap üìù

- **Producers** fuel the system.
- **Biodiversity** creates strength.
- **Biomes** are defined by climate.
- We are part of the ecosystem, not separate from it.
